position.marginalia_text: In vetusto Codice, de Nouis Professoribus: { Novus Medicus, interfector hominum: Novus Iudex, sententia perdita: Novus Sacerdos, tanq[uam] bestia Cornuta. At hodiè, Neographia tota in toto. Quid noui, aut rari? Prima qua[e]stio.

marginalia.translation: In the ancient book, regarding new professors: the new doctor, a killer of men; the new judge, a degenerate sentence; the new priest, like a cuckolded beast. But today, all of Neographia in its entirety. What is new or rare? The first question.
Testing the sun. Trust the expert.

position.marginalia_text: Omne tulit punctu[m], qui miscuit vtile Dulci. Lucianus, finem Historia[e] constituit

X-ref.text: Omne tulit punctum, qui miscuit vtile Dulci

position.marginalia_text: vt juuet: quòd si etiam per se subsequatur
id quoq[ue] tradit magnoperè ad Historiam spectare. Certè, dulci Narratore nihil dulcius.

marginalia.translation: "He who mixed the useful with the sweet won every point." Lucian established that the goal of History is usefulness, something that helps. But even if pleasantness were to follow naturally, such pleasantness would still be devoted mainly to relating History. Certainly, nothing is sweeter than a sweet narrator.

position.marginalia_text: Hoc testamentum exequere: et facilè eris maximaru[m] facultatum ha[e]res.

marginalia.translation: Carry out this will, and you will easily be a disciple of the greatest abilities.

position.marginalia_text:
Decet excellentem Pragmaticu[m], esse in theoricis peritu[m]: in practicis industrium: in dubijs subtilem: in reconditis profundu[m]: in arcanis curiosu[m]: in arduis validum: in laboribus constantem: in aduersis splendidu[m]: in prosperis candidu[m]: in singulis egregium: in omnibus magnificu[m]: et quotieès res postulat, suppetitq[ue] =
= facultas, in pla[e]risq[ue] dictis, factisq[ue] admirabilem. Ad auream Chrysotechni arte[m] decori.
